page.title: 16GLOSSOPDALE REMEMBERED
page.content: {Mrs. Dawson}has lived in{Gamesley}for fortyone years. She left school at 14 and got a job as a shoemaker making sandals. She was paid{eight shillings a week. When Mrs. Dawson was a girl her house looked out over open fields. There was a{Co-op grocer's shop and {butcher's shop}nearby. The shops are still there but now sell goods for 'do-it-yourself' work and are called{ {'The bent nail'!}The road was much quieter as there were few cars. The children went to{school}either at Charlesworth or at Dinting, or if they were Roman Catholics to St.Mary's in Glossop. For{entertainment}people went to the cinema either in Glossop or at Woolley Bridge. The former is now a supermarket and the latter has been demolished. To shop Mrs. Dawson went to Glossop, especially to the indoor and outdoor market.
